bibl.title: Letter from Mary Fishback to Philip Showalter Hench, August 30, 1940

div1.p: Fishback writes that there was very little newspaper coverage of Reed's paper on the transmission of yellow fever, which was presented at the 1900 Public Health Association meeting.

div1.head: Letter from Mary Fishback to Philip Showalter Hench, August 30, 1940
div1.opener:
INDIANAPOLIS PUBLIC LIBRARY
MERIDIAN AT SAINT CLAIR
INDIANAPOLIS, INDIANA
L. L. DICKERSON
LIBRARIAN
Reference Department
P. S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench-
div1.p:
In reply to your request of
August 26, we have very little to give you
from the Indianapolis newspapers, about Dr. Reed's
paper at the meeting of the Public Health
Association. Although the papers covered the
meetings pretty thoroughly, they seem to have
given most attention to local men.

The Indianapolis Journal, October 24, 1900, had the
following:

“By special courtesy of the convention, manifested
through unanimous vote, Dr. Walter Reed was granted
time to read a paper containing results of some
investigations of infectious diseases in Cuba, made
under the direction of Surgeon General Sternberg.
Dr. Reed's paper proved so fascinating that when the
twenty minutes time limit expired another vote was
taken ... extension of time was granted him.”

The Indianapolis Sentinel of same date, said, “the
article was listened to with absorbing interest.”

In the News, which might have been expected to
give much space to such a paper, we could find no
mention of Dr. Reed's. We also failed to find any
editorial comments on any of the meetings.

You can understand there is nothing worth being
photostated.
